review.title: Construction of Vietnamese SentiWordNet by using Vietnamese Dictionary
review.abstract: SentiWordNet is an important lexical resource supporting sentiment analysis in opinion mining applications. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to construct a Vietnamese SentiWordNet (VSWN). SentiWordNet is typically generated from WordNet in which each synset has numerical scores to indicate its opinion polarities. Many previous studies obtained these scores by applying a machine learning method to WordNet. However, Vietnamese WordNet is not available unfortunately by the time of this paper. Therefore, we propose a method to construct VSWN from a Vietnamese dictionary, not from WordNet. We show the effectiveness of the proposed method by generating a VSWN with 39,561 synsets automatically. The method is experimentally tested with 266 synsets with aspect of positivity and negativity. It attains a competitive result compared with English SentiWordNet that is 0.066 and 0.052 differences for positivity and negativity sets respectively.

metadata.title: Construction of Vietnamese SentiWordNet by using Vietnamese Dictionary

sections.text: SentiWordNet is an important lexical resource to support sentiment analysis in opinion polls. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to constructing a Vietnamese SentiWordNet (VSWN). SentiWordNet is typically generated from WordNet, in which each synset has numerical values to display its opinion polarities. Many previous studies have obtained these values by applying a machine learning method to WordNet. Unfortunately, Vietnamese WordNet is not available at the time of this essay. Therefore, we propose a method for constructing VSWN from a Vietnamese dictionary, not from WordNet. We demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method by automatically generating a VSWN with 39,561 synsets. The method is tested experimentally with 266 synsets in terms of positivity and negativity, and achieves a competitive result compared to the English SentiWordNet, which has a net of 0.066 or 0.052 differences respectively.

sections.heading: 2. Related Work
sections.text: In this section, we will show the structures of SentiWordNet, current research on SentiwordNet. Additionally, we will describe the structures of Vdict, a part of the VLSP project that will replace WordNet in this work.

sections.heading: 2.1 SentiWordNet
sections.text: SentiWordNet is first introduced by Esuli et al. with ESWN 1.0 [1] Net, which is explicitly designed to support the opinion environment. ESWN is commented by WordNet by automatically adding the terms "positivity," "negativity" and "neutrality" for each synset. In SentiWordNet, Synset is a set of synonymous terms. A synset is defined as a tuple containing 6 fields, including POS (part of the speech), ID (synset identifier), PosScore (positive score), Negative Score (negative score), Term (a word representing a concept), Gloss (a definition of the term and an example sentence using the term) delimited by a < tab >. Although the neutral score of a synset s is not mentioned, it can easily be derived from the information of a synset.

sections.heading: 2.2 Vietnamese Dictionary
sections.text: As illustrated from the outset, the available lexical resources for Vietnamese are limited, except for Vdict, which is useful for generating VSWN. Vdict is a well-formal dictionary using XML language. It consists of 39,561 terms in which each term contains essential information about morphology, syntactics and semantics sufficient to derive synthetic information. Figure 1 contains sematic information about the term p "beautiful." sections.heading: 3. Generating VSWN
sections.text: After examining the construction of ESWN 3.0, ISWN, in conjunction with the available resources for Vietnamese, we consulted the following assessments: (1) the method of creating ESWN 3.0 is a prominent method when the WordNet is available, and (2) the method of building ISWN is only appropriate with the construction of the original SentiWordNet, as it depends entirely on machine translation, but there are major problems in applying the method of ESWN 3.0: (1) There are no available seed sets, as Turney and Littman [9] (TLSeeds) have contributed in Vietnamese, and (2) WordNet for Vietnamese is not available at the time of this essay. Finally, we propose to use translation methods to replace TLSeeds, and then the method of machine learning to generate VSWN from Vdict. Here we describe in detail our approach to constructing VSWN.

sections.heading: 3.1 Framework overview
sections.text: The overview of our approach is illustrated in Figure 2. In our approach there are two main phases: (1) construction of the VSWN core phase and (2) semi-supervised learning phase. The objectivity of the first phase consists in obtaining VSWN core from ESWN. In the second phase we construct two classifiers using the VSWN core to calculate opinion-related properties for all synsets. Further details about these two phases are described in the following subsections.

sections.heading: 4. Experiment
sections.text: To get the most effective SentiWordNet, the two classifiers must have the highest performance. Therefore, we use different experiments to evaluate and select the most advantageous parameters to perform an opinion-based calculation task.

sections.heading: 4.1 Dataset
sections.text: From the extended VSWN core step described in 3.3, we obtained the training data in a ratio of 847 positive glosses, 449 neutral glosses and 1232 negative glosses. These data are divided into three sets, including (1) training set, (2) development set and (3) test set in a ratio of 3: 1: 1. Specifically, we perform a quadruple validation of the training set and development set to select the most appropriate parameters that would then be applied to the test set to obtain the final classification performance. As the positive classifier and negative classifier use the same combination method from the same training data, we only measure the classification performance of the positive classifier thanks to the performance of the negative classifier, would change the same or slightly, but not be too different from the positive classifier. The evaluation step should focus only on how good the SentiWordNet is, rather than performing the evaluation task at application level. Therefore, we have decided to use a gold standard to measure our contributing SentiWordNet. In the evaluation step, Kanddall tau () distance is used to measure the resulting VSWN. Table 2 reports the values for thepositivity and negativity classifications, measured against the standard wording list.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have presented a thorough examination of SentiWordNet's construction methods for generating VSWN. Our main contributions to this work are three: (1) building a semantic wordlist for the Vietnamese gold standard for evaluation; (2) generating VSWN without using Vietnamese WordNet; and (3) proving that the resulting VSWN is worth another study. Since the glosses in Vdict are short texts, performance easily suffers from a problem of thrift. Therefore, solving the thrift problem to achieve better performance is our essential further study.
